user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of add_session_cookie:
```c
static void
add_session_cookie (struct Session *session,
                    struct MHD_Response *response)
{
  char cstr[256];
  snprintf (cstr,
            sizeof (cstr),
            "%s=%s",
            COOKIE_NAME,
            session->sid);
  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_SET_COOKIE,
                               cstr))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set session cookie header!\n");
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function add_session_cookie:
#define COOKIE_NAME "session"
...
struct Session
{
  /**
   * We keep all sessions in a linked list.
   */
  struct Session *next;

  /**
   * Unique ID for this session.
   */
  char sid[33];

  /**
   * Reference counter giving the number of connections
   * currently using this session.
   */
  unsigned int rc;

  /**
   * Time when this session was last active.
   */
  time_t start;

  /**
   * String submitted via form.
   */
  char value_1[64];

  /**
   * Another value submitted via form.
   */
  char value_2[64];

}
...
struct MHD_Response
...
#define MHD_HTTP_HEADER_SET_COOKIE "Set-Cookie"
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No calls to the <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) appear in the provided code fragment or related definitions. The only string operation in add_session_cookie is snprintf, which is from <stdio.h>, not <string.h>, and it is invoked with an explicit destination size (sizeof(cstr)), preventing writes beyond cstr. Given the provided definitions (COOKIE_NAME == "session" length 7, session->sid is char[33] allowing up to 32 characters plus NUL), the formatted result cannot exceed cstr[256] and so will not cause a buffer overrun in this function. Therefore there are no code fragments here that fall under Rule 21.17 and need further investigation. (Note: if session->sid were not NUL-terminated due to other code, a %s conversion would read past its bounds, but that is a potential issue with printf-family usage and/or how sid is produced elsewhere — it is not a use of the <string.h> functions named in Rule 21.17 and thus outside this rule's direct scope.)
